title: 112_hr6574
content: The Act may be cited as the "Servicemember Mental Health Review Act". Since September 11, 2001, around 30,000 veterans have been discharged from the Armed Forces due to personality or adjustment disorders. These veterans are then unable to access disability compensation, severance pay, or retirement pay. Additionally, many of them struggle to find employment due to the stigma associated with their discharge label. Many veterans separated for personality or adjustment disorders face challenges in finding employment due to the stigma associated with their discharge label. The Department of Defense had low regulatory compliance in separating members based on these disorders between 2001 and 2007. A Mental Health Discharge Board of Review is proposed to review such separations. Between 2001 and  2007, the rate of veterans separated for personality or adjustment disorders was as low as 40 percent. A Mental Health Discharge Board of Review is recommended to ensure veterans wrongly separated on these grounds can access disability benefits and employment opportunities. The Department of Defense is reviewing military separations based on mental conditions that do not amount to disability. The Department of Defense is amending Chapter 79 of title 10, United States Code to establish Mental Health Discharge Boards of Review within each military department to review separations based on mental conditions not amounting to disability. The Department of Defense is establishing Mental Health Discharge Boards of Review within each military department to review separations of covered individuals from the armed forces with mental conditions not amounting to disability. Each board will consist of at least five members, including a licensed psychologist and psychiatrist. The Secretary of each military department will provide adequate administrative and behavioral health support staff for the boards. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review will consist of at least five members, including a licensed psychologist and psychiatrist. Covered individuals are members and former members of the armed forces separated since September 11, 2001, due to mental conditions not amounting to disability. The Secretary of each military department will equip the board with necessary support staff. The Secretary of Defense ensures that covered individuals are notified of their right to a review by the Mental Health Discharge Board of Review for separations from the armed forces due to mental conditions not amounting to disability. The Secretary of Defense ensures covered individuals are notified of their right to a review by the Mental Health Discharge Board of Review for separations from the armed forces. The Secretary of the military department is responsible for providing the notification, and any failures to comply must be promptly reported to Congress. If a covered individual does not receive notification, they or their representative may file a complaint. The Secretary of Defense ensures covered individuals are notified of their right to a review by the Mental Health Discharge Board of Review for separations from the armed forces. If a covered individual does not receive notification, they or their representative may file a request for review. The notification must inform the individual of their right to obtain legal counsel for representation. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review shall inform covered individuals of their right to obtain private counsel for representation and provide a list of organizations that may offer counsel at no cost. The Board will review the findings of the Department of Defense psychologist or psychiatrist, as well as the decisions of the separation authority for each covered individual. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review will consider the psychologist or psychiatrist's findings, the separation authority's decisions, and the adherence to separation processes. The review will be based on records from the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs, along with any additional evidence presented. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review will base its review on records from the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs, along with any other evidence presented, including private mental health records. If the Board decides to conduct a review on its own, the covered individual will be notified. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review will notify the covered individual or their representative before conducting a review. After completing the review, the board must provide the claimant with the outcome. After completing the review, the Mental Health Discharge Board of Review must provide the claimant with a statement of reasons for their decision. The covered individual can request a reconsideration if new evidence is available. The board may recommend actions to the Secretary of the military department based on their findings. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review may recommend actions to the Secretary of the military department based on their findings, including no negative recharacterization of separation, retirement for disability, or recharacterization of separation. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review may recommend actions to the Secretary of the military department, including recharacterization of separation to retirement for disability, separation for disability with severance pay, separation upon expiration of term of service, separation for convenience of the Government, and issuance of a new disability rating for the individual. Compliance with Administrative Procedure Act Transparency is required. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review may recommend recharacterization of separation to retirement for disability, separation with severance pay, separation upon expiration of term of service, or separation for convenience of the Government. If a recharacterization is not recommended, a brief statement of reasons must be provided. Compliance with Administrative Procedure Act Transparency is required. The Mental Health Discharge Board of Review may recommend different types of separation for covered individuals, including retirement for disability. If a recommendation is not made, a brief statement of reasons must be provided. The military department concerned must correct the individual's military records based on the Board's recommendation. The military department corrects the records of covered individuals based on recommendations from the Mental Health Discharge Board of Review. Corrections are effective as of the separation date. If a covered individual received a lump-sum payment at separation, their future benefits will be adjusted accordingly. The amount of pay or benefits for individuals based on military record corrections will be reduced if they received a lump-sum payment at separation. Regulations for this section will be set by the Secretary of Defense, with specified deadlines for required reviews. The regulations under paragraph (1) will set deadlines for required reviews. The Secretary of Defense must establish Mental Health Discharge Boards of Review within 90 days of the enactment of the Act, as required by section 1554b of title 10, United States Code. Regulations for this process must also be prescribed.
